Since I'm taking part in the international school project Global Shakespeare, I thought it would be interesting to research in which warf Shakespeare entered our German hearts.

While asking the world wide web the same question, I found an article called Wie Shakespeares Denkmal in den Weimarer Ilmpark kam, written by Wolfgang Hirsch and published in the Th√ºringer Allgemeine on 24th April 2016.
According to Klaus Manger, a professor of germanistic, Christoph Martin Wieland was the first author to translate Shakespearean dramas into German.
Between 1762 until 1766 were published 22 of Shakespearean dramatic literature.

However, other German authors were influenced by Shakespearean work as well, like Lessing, Goethe or Herder who were to become the so-called representation of the German Shakespeare Renaissance in Weimar
For a long time there has been the belief in Germany that Wieland's work has been influenced by other German authors as well, who were prejudiced for putting nonsense in their reader's minds.
Manger however finds Wieland's work extraordinary allthoughalthough there are more modern versions on the market from authors like Fred, Schaller, or Stein.
The first known Shakespearean performance in Germany was on the 8th April 1864.
It took place in Weimar and was presented by the Verein der Shakespeare-Freunde.
Franz von Dingelstedt presented sequences of Shakespearean work and inspired the audience so much that on the same day the oldest German Shakespearean community has been founded.
In a park in Weimar, on the 23rd April 1904 was a statue of Shakespeare built by Lessing.
This statue won the UNESCOUnited Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization prize as well.
So, although there are still performances of Shakespeare in cities like Bochum, it all started in Weimar.
